abstract.p: Lincoln Center Out-of-Doors begins its 30th season of free performances and activities with family play day followed by concert featuring jazz saxophonist Sonny Rollins in Damrosch Park; SlamAmerica, tour of performance poets, is set to visit cities in Midwest and East; exhibition of works on paper by artist Georgia O'Keeffe is running at Georgia O'Keeffe Museum, Santa Fe, NM; Jeff Manookian to conduct Pasadena Symphony Orchestra and Oratorio Society of Utah in West Coast premiere performance of his oratoria Symphony of Tears, Pasadena; photos (M)

block.p: Lincoln Center Out-of-Doors begins its 30th season of free performances and activities on Saturday with a family play day beginning at 2 p.m. that includes dancers, the Puppeteers' Cooperative and a profusion of percussion. On Saturday night at 8 a program called ''Jazz Takes Flight'' features the saxophonist Sonny Rollins at the band shell in Damrosch Park. This year's festival, with a theme of ''Celebrate Good Times!,'' continues through Aug. 27. Information: (212) 875-5108.

Lincoln Center Out-of-Doors begins its 30th season of free performances and activities on Saturday with a family play day beginning at 2 p.m. that includes dancers, the Puppeteers' Cooperative and a profusion of percussion. On Saturday night at 8 a program called ''Jazz Takes Flight'' features the saxophonist Sonny Rollins at the band shell in Damrosch Park. This year's festival, with a theme of ''Celebrate Good Times!,'' continues through Aug. 27. Information: (212) 875-5108.

SlamAmerica, a coast-to-coast tour of performance poets, rolls into cities in the Midwest and East. At each Poetry Slam event, 15 to 25 poets exchange three-minute samples of their own supercharged verse in a high-energy competition. The tour arrives in Detroit tomorrow (information and reservations: 313-873-7238), Cleveland on Wednesday (440-255-1124), Washington on Thursday (301-662-1369) and Baltimore on Friday (301-662-1369). On Saturday night the action moves to Manhattan; slamming begins at 7 at Nell's, 246 West 14th Street, West Village (212-614-3040).

Watercolors, pastels and charcoals -- 55 works, many from private collections -- have been assembled in ''O'Keeffe on Paper,'' an exhibition running through Oct. 29 at the Georgia O'Keeffe Museum in Santa Fe, N.M. The show, organized by the museum and the National Gallery of Art in Washington, spans 50 years beginning in 1915. It illuminates a little-known aspect of O'Keeffe's work, exploring her technical ability while tracing the development of her artistic language. Information: (505) 995-0785.

''Symphony of Tears,'' an oratorio by Jeff Manookian, will receive its West Coast premiere on Saturday night at 8 at the Civil Auditorium in Pasadena, Calif. Mr. Manookian will conduct the Pasadena Symphony Orchestra and the Oratorio Society of Utah. The work, based on an original text by Bradford Nelson and selections from Armenian liturgy and inspired by the experiences of the composer's grandfather, commemorates the killings of thousands of Armenians by Turks in 1915. Information: (626) 584-8833.
